title: Should Parents Sit with Kids During Math Homework?
description: Finding the right balance between support and independence when it comes to math homework time.
imageAlt: Parent sitting with child during homework

content.intro: Should you sit right next to your child during math homework? Or should they learn to work independently? The answer isn't all-or-nothing.

rows: Parent ends up doing the work

sections.text: The sweet spot is somewhere in between.
Sit nearby. Young kids need supervision and frequent check-ins. Read directions together. Be available for questions.
Transition period. Start homework together, then step back. Check in periodically. Review completed work.
Nearby but not hovering. Available when asked. Check completed work occasionally. Teach them to use resources.
A balanced approach that works for many families:

items: Set up homework together (materials, space, expectations)
Be in the same room, doing your own task
Establish a signal for when they need help
Respond to questions with questions first
Check work at the end together
You're doing more work than they are

sections.text: The goal is gradual release. Start close, step back as they show readiness. If they regress, step closer again temporarily.

faq.question: My child won't do homework unless I sit with them. What do I do?
faq.answer: Start where they are, but work toward independence. Gradually increase the time between check-ins. Make sure they know you're available but that they can start without you.

faq.question: I get frustrated watching them make mistakes. Help?
faq.answer: Mistakes are learning opportunities. Try not to correct immediately â€“ let them discover errors themselves when possible. If you can't stay calm, step back physically.

faq.question: Should I correct wrong answers before they turn it in?
faq.answer: Generally no. Teachers need to see what students don't understand. Help them find errors, but don't fix everything. It's okay to turn in imperfect work.
